image.altText: A boy and his dad smiling together while on a mountain.

props.synopsis: The death of Charlie Stevens, the SA police commissioner's son, caused grief in the community that was shared by many who felt a bond with the commissioner, including many in the media.

title.children: Charlie Stevens was the 101st person to die on SA's roads this year. His death had a profound impact

image.altText: A police officer speaks to the media.

props.synopsis: Victoria Police Detective Senior Sergeant Paul Lineham has been temporarily appointed as a Special Constable and will have control of the direction and outcome of the investigation.

title.children: Independent investigator appointed to oversee Charlie Stevens investigation

image.altText: A composite image of two women and one young boy.

props.synopsis: Day one of a temporary ceasefire in the Israel-Gaza war ends with Hamas releasing about double the number of hostages previously announced by authorities and 39 Palestinian prisoners being freed from Israeli jails.

title.children: Surprise as extra hostages released on tense first day of Israel-Gaza ceasefire

image.altText: Fahad at Red Rooster

props.synopsis: You might think all students stand equal at the doorstep of Australiaâ€™s universities. But when Fahad tried to become a doctor, he had to navigate a system that seemed to punish him.

title.children: The odds of becoming a doctor when you live west of the 'Red Rooster line'

image.altText: a woman smiling under the sun

props.synopsis: The Queensland government allowed its mine safety commissioner Kate du Preez to keep acting in her role after accepting a lucrative job offer from a coal giant that has multiple convictions over workplace deaths and injuries, ABC Investigations has found.

title.children: Coal giant headhunts commissioner who oversaw agency investigating it for workplace deaths

image.altText: A man in winter coat and scarf in front of a mountain and building.

props.synopsis: The mother of a victim who was groomed by a former Yorke Peninsula teacher has criticised her son's abuser, saying he used the region as a "hunting ground" to pick out the most vulnerable children that would not speak up.

title.children: Victim's family hit back at child sex abuser's 'no substance' apology

image.altText: a person standing outdoors on a wheat farme next to machinery with storm clouds brewing and their arms up high

props.synopsis: As Western Australia sweats through the hottest November on record, eastern states are rejoicing through an extended run of stormy days.

title.children: Eastern storm outbreak saves spring while WA bakes in record-hot November

image.altText: mother lucy bloom standing outside randwick girls high school looking at the camera

props.synopsis: News that two schools in the city's east will be joining to go co-ed in a few years' time has split the community. It's not the first time such a move has stirred debate in Sydney.

title.children: Family considers having daughter 'drop out' as Sydney all-girls school plans to go co-ed

image.altText: A photo of Anthony Albanese's cabinet posing for a photo around a large oval table

props.synopsis: Between Australia's economic situation and the crisis in the Middle East, there has been a growing sense that the government is not in control of eventsÂ â€” and it's throwing out lots of chaff, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Between crises at home and abroad, the government is striving to show it's hard at work. You just have to sort through the chaff

image.altText: A man squats over fire damaged posessions

props.synopsis: Residents whose homes have been destroyed and lives turned upside down by a massive fire that's torn through Perth's north-east return to their properties to pick up the pieces.

title.children: Yohann Catherine and his family didn't take the Perth fire seriously. Now they have 'nothing left'

image.altText: A gun being fired off a boat on the ocean with blue sky above

props.synopsis: Just days after a Chinese warship caused minor injuries to Australian defence personnel, the US Navy is warning Beijing to respect international law.

title.children: United States warns China to be 'safe and professional' following sonar attack on Australian naval divers

image.altText: Sigrid Thornton, a 64-year-old white woman with curly brown hair wearing a white blouse and black pants leans against a railing.

props.synopsis: Most Australians would know her from her screen roles, but theatre has been a drawcard for the veteran actor in recent years and she's about to take on one of her meatiest roles yet.

title.children: 'A strange world full of unusual characters': Sigrid Thornton takes on Chekhov's greatest diva

image.altText: A man trapped inside a tunnel wears a white hard hat as he looks into a camera for a low resolution picture.

props.synopsis: Forty-one men have been stranded inside a 2-kilometre stretch of a collapsed tunnel in the Himalayas for almost two weeks.Â So how did they end up in there and what have conditions been like as they await a cautious rescue mission?

title.children: How did the 41 workers trapped inside a collapsed Himalayan highway tunnel survive for almost two weeks?

image.altText: Young teacher Brittany Herrington standing in a colourful Year 5 classroom.

props.synopsis: "Unsustainable workloads" and children with increasingly complex needs are among the reasons why more and more teachers are considering quitting, according to a new union survey.

title.children: This young teacher has spent $17,000 of her own money trying to support her students

image.altText: Lisa McManus is a thalidomide survivor

props.synopsis: Lisa McManus wasÂ born with deformities after her mum took a morning sickness drug during pregnancy. She's been waiting years for the government to apologise for allowing thalidomideÂ on Australian shelves.

title.children: Trish's mum took thalidomide. She can't be there to hear the government's apology, but the 'guilt will be there to her last breath'

image.altText: A man and a woman stand on stage waving at a crowd of people.

props.synopsis: There is a strong desire for things to change in Argentina, but will a politician famous for his eccentricity and who used to be a tantric sex coach be able to do as his fans beg of him and "make Argentina great again?"

title.children: Cloned dogs, chainsaws and an iconic mop of hair: Meet Argentina's new firebrand president

image.altText: A women with dark red hair faces the camera with a somber expression on her face.

props.synopsis: Asherman's syndrome is under-diagnosed, misunderstood, and can lead to infertility. A group of mothers are campaigning for changes to protect women from a common medical procedure that can lead to a diagnosis.

title.children: 'I wish I had known': Women demand changes to medical procedure that can cause infertility

image.altText: Charred ground on the porch of a home destroyed in a bushfire, with windows scorched and burnt out.

props.synopsis: The massive bushfire that destroyed 18 homes in Perth's north is no longer being treated as an emergency level fire as the wind and heat eases across the city.

title.children: Emergency threat passes for residents in line of fire as Perth weather conditions ease

image.altText: Figuring out how to save money on energy bill

props.synopsis: The retail price of electricity has an in-built 12-month lag by design. This means the energy bill relief could be in place now, but the system does not allow it, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Your electricity bills could be a lot cheaper right now, if only the system would allow it

image.altText: An unidentified teenager stands next to wire fence and checks a phone

props.synopsis: As hospitalisations associated with knife attacks rise amid a string of high-profile deaths of young people, the way Victoria deals with children who use weapons in pursuit of violence is becoming an increasingly delicate and politically divisive question.

title.children: Behind the scenes of Victoria's youth crime problem, the best response is proving divisive

image.altText: A smashed window on a mobile speed camera car.

props.synopsis: In Sally's former line of work it was not unusual to have eggs thrown at her car, her windows smashed, or her tyres slashed.

title.children: Speed camera operators cite abuse, attacks as part of the job â€” including claims of 'hostile' employer

image.altText: A person films themselves cooking through an iphone.

props.synopsis: More and more social media seems like an all-in adult version of children's playground games, where nobody's ever out, and where the game â€” and the joke â€” just goes round and round, writes Virginia Trioli.Â

title.children: I don't know who needs to hear this, but ... the playground imitation games of social media are getting old

image.altText: A woman in high vis stands in a dug out hole in a field with her arms up in celebration.

props.synopsis: The rules meant to protect Australia's natural history can be tricky to comprehend. Here's what you should do if you ever come across a fossil or an artefact.

title.children: Think you've found a fossil? Here's what you should â€” and shouldn't â€” do next

image.altText: A woman standing by a window.

props.synopsis: Vivian Li didn't realise she had ADHD until she was an adult â€” but that's a common experience for many people in China.Â

title.children: What it's like to be diagnosed with ADHD as an adult in China

image.altText: Adam Scott pulls the club back and prepares to hit it as the gallery looks on

props.synopsis: Golf has endured a year of bad press, with both the amateur and professional games mired in political and economic disputes. But on the ground at the Australian PGA Championship, reasons to be hopeful abound.

title.children: Australia's summer of golf might yet save the soul of a troubled sport

image.altText: A lady in a hijab sitting

props.synopsis: Iranian cinema has long been the darling of the international film festival circuit, earning praise and awards at prestigious film festivals. But protests across Iran sparked by the death-in-custody of Mahsa Jina Amini in September 2022 ushered in a new kind of challenge for filmmakers working under the strict censorship rules of the Islamic Republic.Â

title.children: How a film festival in Australia was almost called off as Iranian filmmakers grapple with a government crackdown

image.altText: a zoomed out picture of a ship in the middle of the ocean

props.synopsis: Taiwan's defence ministry said an Australian ship, understood to be the HMAS Toowoomba, has sailed through the strategic waterway, after its personnel were injured by a Chinese sonar pulse.Â

title.children: China reacts after Australian warship HMAS Toowoomba transits Taiwan Strait

image.altText: A close-up shot of a man with short hair and a stubble, not looking happy.

props.synopsis: South African Paralympian Oscar Pistorius is granted parole after serving 10 years for the 2013 murder of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.

title.children: Oscar Pistorius granted parole after serving 10 years for the murder of Reeva Steenkamp

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann arrives with coffee at the Federal Court.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann is suing Network Ten and Lisa Wilkinson over coverage in which Brittany Higgins alleged she was raped in Parliament House in 2019.

title.children: 'I was wrong': Bruce Lehrmann concedes he bought drinks for Brittany Higgins despite earlier saying he couldn't recall

image.altText: A black F1 car leads a red F1 car through a hair-pin turn

props.synopsis: Red Bull are guaranteed first, Alpine will finish sixth, but the finishing position of the other eight teams is undecided.

title.children: Millions of dollars at stake as F1 teams enter final round with everything to race for

image.altText: Australian tennis coach Lleyton Hewitt congratulates Alexei Popyrin as both men smile after a win in a Davis Cup match.

props.synopsis: Australia's men's tennis team believe no-one will want to play them after they beat Finland to reach back-to-back Davis Cup finals in Malaga.

title.children: De Minaur, Popyrin power Australia into Davis Cup final with win over Finland

image.altText: A large crowd of protestors outside Flinders Street Station. One student waves a Palestinian flag in the air.

props.synopsis: Pro-Palestinian rallies have been going on for weeks across the country. The protests are dominated by young people.

title.children: Hundreds of high school students break the rules in walkout for pro-Palestine protest

image.altText: Kate wears a black sparkly mini-dress and poses with a hand on her hip in front of a dark library wall.

props.synopsis: "There's a narrative out there that these women are vapid, brainless and ridiculous. But that's not true. They're pretty powerful womenâ€¦ and they have more influence than what you think they might," says Real Housewives of Sydney cast member Dr Kate Adams.

title.children: This Real Housewife of Sydney has a career, isn't married and doesn't want kids. Here's why she's on the series
